elements.content: The use of monocarboxylic acid along with dicarboxylic acid significantly influences the nucleation–growth– transformation process in crystals of metal–organic frameworks. Usually the acetic acid is used as a coordination modulator to control the morphology and size of crystals. We have explored here the effect of acetic acid on the structures where the secondary building unit is a trimer. The acetic acid binds with the metal ion and induces structural transformation with anisotropic crystal growth. The acetic acid bonded structures are found to have magnetic long-range ordering at low temperature. Moreover the bonding fashion of the acetate ion creates a chiral center in the framework due to spontaneous resolution of the achiral building units. We have proposed a possible mechanism for this acetic acid driven transformation by analyzing the powder X-ray diffraction patterns and single crystal structure. Thus, this work not only provides a strategy to synthesize new designed structures using mixed carboxylic acid ligands but also sheds light on the structural transformation and magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: The use of monocarboxylic acid along with dicarboxylic acid significantly influences the nucleation-growth- transformation process in crystals of metal-organic frameworks. Usually the acetic acid is used as a coordination modulator to control the morphology and size of crystals. We have explored here the effect of acetic acid on the structures where the secondary building unit is a trimer. The acetic acid binds with the metal ion and induces structural transformation with anisotropic crystal growth. The acetic acid bonded structures are found to have magnetic long-range ordering at low temperature. Moreover the bonding fashion of the acetate ion creates a chiral center in the framework due to spontaneous resolution of the achiral building units. We have proposed a possible mechanism for this acetic acid driven transformation by analyzing the powder X-ray diffraction patterns and single crystal structure. Thus, this work not only provides a strategy to synthesize new designed structures using mixed carboxylic acid ligands but also sheds light on the structural transformation and magnetic properties.

elements.content: The role of monocarboxylic acid in modifying the structure of metal−organic frameworks has been explored. The acetic acid bridges the trimer secondary building units and forms a one-dimensional chain. The structural transformation has been studied in single crystals. This transformation leads to long-range magnetic ordering in those compounds.
elements.clean_text: The role of monocarboxylic acid in modifying the structure of metal-organic frameworks has been explored. The acetic acid bridges the trimer secondary building units and forms a one-dimensional chain. The structural transformation has been studied in single crystals. This transformation leads to long-range magnetic ordering in those compounds.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, research on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has received great attention owing to their plethora of applications in various fields of science. The overall control of synthesis of these hybrid materials is challenging due to several controlling parameters. It is generally accepted that the factors like the molar ratio of the starting materials, metal source, solvent, temperature, and pH of the reaction medium control the size and morphology of the crystals and dimensionality of the structure. The morphogenesis and downsizing of MOF crystals to a micro/nano regime have attracted more attention due to their diverse applications in material science. Use of mono dentate ligands like acetic acid, benzoic acid, formic acid, trimethylamine, pyridine, etc. has been explored as a modulator or template to control the growth of single crystals through the coordination modulation method. The modulators exhibit a competing interaction with the ligand which is used for the synthesis of MOFs and thus limits the growth in a particular direction. The control of morphology and size has great interest in sensing, gas adsorption, and biological applications, etc.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few decades, research on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has received great attention owing to their plethora of applications in various fields of science. The overall control of synthesis of these hybrid materials is challenging due to several controlling parameters. It is generally accepted that the factors like the molar ratio of the starting materials, metal source, solvent, temperature, and pH of the reaction medium control the size and morphology of the crystals and dimensionality of the structure. The morphogenesis and downsizing of MOF crystals to a micro/nano regime have attracted more attention due to their diverse applications in material science. Use of mono dentate ligands like acetic acid, benzoic acid, formic acid, trimethylamine, pyridine, etc. has been explored as a modulator or template to control the growth of single crystals through the coordination modulation method. The modulators exhibit a competing interaction with the ligand which is used for the synthesis of MOFs and thus limits the growth in a particular direction. The control of morphology and size has great interest in sensing, gas adsorption, and biological applications, etc.

elements.content: There are many reports where the role of the mono dentate ligand, metal coordination, and stability of metal-oxo clusters in tuning the morphology and size of crystals has been discussed. Kitagawa and co-workers have shown how acetic acid acts as a coordination modulator to downsize the crystals of [Cu2(ndc)2­(dabco)] (where ndc = 1, 4-naphthalene dicarboxylate, dabco = diazabicyclo [2.2.2]­octane) to the nano regime. In this case the acetic acid competes with ndc2– linkers which are connected to the Cu-based paddle-wheel units and limits the growth in that particular direction but does not affect the growth along the pillaring direction. Behrens and co-workers used the same technique for the synthesis of nanoscale Zr-based MOFs where Zr forms a cluster in a square-antiprismatic geometry by bridging with μ3-O, μ3-OH, and carboxylate groups. However, the use of acetic acid plays a different role where the secondary building unit (SBU) is a linear dimer or trimer. Recently Kasel and co-workers have shown that acetic acid acts as a coligand instead of a modulator in the case of MOF with trimer as secondary building unit. From these observations we may conclude that the coordination mode and rigidity of metal-oxo cluster determine the role of acetic acid. The paddlewheel and cage like metal-oxo clusters are highly rigid and robust due to their specific geometry. Therefore, acetic acid cannot bind to those clusters, which will be energetically unfavorable, whereas the dimeric or trimeric clusters are more labile, and hence the acetic acid binds to the metal ion.
elements.clean_text: There are many reports where the role of the mono dentate ligand, metal coordination, and stability of metal-oxo clusters in tuning the morphology and size of crystals has been discussed. Kitagawa and co-workers have shown how acetic acid acts as a coordination modulator to downsize the crystals of [Cu2(ndc)2(dabco)] (where ndc = 1, 4-naphthalene dicarboxylate, dabco = diazabicyclo [2.2.2]octane) to the nano regime. In this case the acetic acid competes with ndc2- linkers which are connected to the Cu-based paddle-wheel units and limits the growth in that particular direction but does not affect the growth along the pillaring direction. Behrens and co-workers used the same technique for the synthesis of nanoscale Zr-based MOFs where Zr forms a cluster in a square-antiprismatic geometry by bridging with μ3-O, μ3-OH, and carboxylate groups. However, the use of acetic acid plays a different role where the secondary building unit (SBU) is a linear dimer or trimer. Recently Kasel and co-workers have shown that acetic acid acts as a coligand instead of a modulator in the case of MOF with trimer as secondary building unit. From these observations we may conclude that the coordination mode and rigidity of metal-oxo cluster determine the role of acetic acid. The paddlewheel and cage like metal-oxo clusters are highly rigid and robust due to their specific geometry. Therefore, acetic acid cannot bind to those clusters, which will be energetically unfavorable, whereas the dimeric or trimeric clusters are more labile, and hence the acetic acid binds to the metal ion.

elements.content: MOFs with mixed ligands have reached a new level of rational design and construction that involves the synergetic coordination of different ligands and metal ions. Some quite interesting structures can be formed only with a combination of mixed ligands, and this implies the importance and success of the mixed ligands strategy. Because of mixed ligand’s synergistic effect, it creates not only the structural hierarchy but also the interesting chemical and physical properties for many potential applications.
elements.clean_text: MOFs with mixed ligands have reached a new level of rational design and construction that involves the synergetic coordination of different ligands and metal ions. Some quite interesting structures can be formed only with a combination of mixed ligands, and this implies the importance and success of the mixed ligands strategy. Because of mixed ligand's synergistic effect, it creates not only the structural hierarchy but also the interesting chemical and physical properties for many potential applications.

elements.content: We have synthesized four Mn based MOFs using dicarboxylate and monocarboxylate ligands and studied their structural and magnetic properties. The as-synthesized compounds were labeled as 1, [Mn3(BDC)3­(DMA)4]; 2, [Mn3(OH-BDC)3­(DMA)4]; and 1a, [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mn2(BDC)2­(CH3COO)]­·2DMA; and 2a, [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mn2(OH-BDC)2­(CH3COO)]­·H2O. The compounds 1 and 2, where a similar structure to compound 1 has been reported by Li et al. in 2011, form a trimer metal cluster unit, which is linked by the dicarboxylate ligand forming the two-dimensional (2D) structure, while the compounds 1a and 2a form the infinite one-dimensional (1D) chain as the SBU unit through Mn–O–Mn bonding, which are then connected by dicarboxylate ligands to form the three-dimensional (3D) structure. The detailed structural investigation and the similarities in the synthetic procedure prompted us to explore the transformation from 1 to 1a and 2 to 2a, respectively. We have proposed a possible mechanism for this transformation. Magnetic properties of all these compounds have also been investigated and correlated with their structural features.
elements.clean_text: We have synthesized four Mn based MOFs using dicarboxylate and monocarboxylate ligands and studied their structural and magnetic properties. The as-synthesized compounds were labeled as 1, [Mn3(BDC)3(DMA)4]; 2, [Mn3(OH-BDC)3(DMA)4]; and 1a, [(CH3)2NH2][Mn2(BDC)2(CH3COO)]⋅2DMA; and 2a, [(CH3)2NH2][Mn2(OH-BDC)2(CH3COO)]⋅H2O. The compounds 1 and 2, where a similar structure to compound 1 has been reported by Li et al. in 2011, form a trimer metal cluster unit, which is linked by the dicarboxylate ligand forming the two-dimensional (2D) structure, while the compounds 1a and 2a form the infinite one-dimensional (1D) chain as the SBU unit through Mn-O-Mn bonding, which are then connected by dicarboxylate ligands to form the three-dimensional (3D) structure. The detailed structural investigation and the similarities in the synthetic procedure prompted us to explore the transformation from 1 to 1a and 2 to 2a, respectively. We have proposed a possible mechanism for this transformation. Magnetic properties of all these compounds have also been investigated and correlated with their structural features.

elements.content: Compound 1: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid in 3 mL of N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA). Then the whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF (N,N′-dimethylformamide) many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Compound 1: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid in 3 mL of N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA). Then the whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF (N,N'-dimethylformamide) many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

elements.content: Compound 2: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid in 3 mL of DMA and sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid in 3 mL of DMA and sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

elements.content: Compound 1a: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and 2 mL of acetic acid was added to this. The solution was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was put into a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 6 days. Colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1a: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and 2 mL of acetic acid was added to this. The solution was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was put into a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 6 days. Colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

elements.content: Compound 2a: To the solution of 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 3 mL of methanol, 2 mL of acetic acid was added and the mixture was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in oven for 3 days. The collected colorless crystals were washed with DMF many times and dried under a vacuum for further use.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2a: To the solution of 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 3 mL of methanol, 2 mL of acetic acid was added and the mixture was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in oven for 3 days. The collected colorless crystals were washed with DMF many times and dried under a vacuum for further use.

elements.content:
Crystals of compound 1 were taken in a glass vial, and then 2 mL of acetic acid was added. The mixture was kept at 100 °C for 6 days. The needle-shaped crystals were formed.

Transformation of <bold>2</bold> to <bold>2a</bold>

The crystals of compound 2a were synthesized by immersing the crystals of compound 2 in 2 mL of acetic acid in a glass vial and then heated at 100 °C 6 days.

Results and DiscussionStructural Description

These four compounds can be classified into two categories: compounds 1 and 2 can be grouped into one category since those compounds have a resemblance in their structural features. These compounds have the same kind of metal and ligand connectivity and network topology. Compound 1 was crystallized in the triclinic crystal system with P1̅ space group, whereas 2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with the P21/n space group. The asymmetric unit of structure 1 consists of three metal ions, three ligand molecules, and four coordinated organic solvent molecules, and 2 consists of one and half of metal ion, one and half ligand, and two coordinated dimethylacetamide molecules (a,b). The inorganic cluster in both the compounds is the Mn3(OCO)6 unit, which is linked via a bidentate functionalized organic linker molecules forming a 2D network (c). In the trimer unit, there are two crystallographically independent Mn ions; both have the coordination number six and adopt a distorted octahedral geometry. One Mn2+ ion is coordinated to six carboxylate oxygen atoms, whereas other Mn2+ which are symmetry generated to form the two terminal centers coordinated to four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two oxygen atoms from solvent molecules. The structural features of compound 2 is similar to that of compound 1, except terephthalic acid is replaced by 2-hydroxy-terephthalic acid (Figures S1 and S2). These 2D layers in both compounds are connected by noncovalent interactions between the coordinated solvent molecules (Figure S3). Each trimer unit is connected to six other trimer units via ligand molecules forming a 6-c connected network (d,e).
elements.clean_text:
Transformation of 1 to 1a 

Crystals of compound 1 were taken in a glass vial, and then 2 mL of acetic acid was added. The mixture was kept at 100 °C for 6 days. The needle-shaped crystals were formed.

Transformation of 2 to 2a 

The crystals of compound 2a were synthesized by immersing the crystals of compound 2 in 2 mL of acetic acid in a glass vial and then heated at 100 °C 6 days.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description

These four compounds can be classified into two categories: compounds 1 and 2 can be grouped into one category since those compounds have a resemblance in their structural features. These compounds have the same kind of metal and ligand connectivity and network topology. Compound 1 was crystallized in the triclinic crystal system with P1̅ space group, whereas 2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with the P21/n space group. The asymmetric unit of structure 1 consists of three metal ions, three ligand molecules, and four coordinated organic solvent molecules, and 2 consists of one and half of metal ion, one and half ligand, and two coordinated dimethylacetamide molecules (a,b). The inorganic cluster in both the compounds is the Mn3(OCO)6 unit, which is linked via a bidentate functionalized organic linker molecules forming a 2D network (c). In the trimer unit, there are two crystallographically independent Mn ions; both have the coordination number six and adopt a distorted octahedral geometry. One Mn2+ ion is coordinated to six carboxylate oxygen atoms, whereas other Mn2+ which are symmetry generated to form the two terminal centers coordinated to four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two oxygen atoms from solvent molecules. The structural features of compound 2 is similar to that of compound 1, except terephthalic acid is replaced by 2-hydroxy-terephthalic acid (Figures S1 and S2). These 2D layers in both compounds are connected by noncovalent interactions between the coordinated solvent molecules (Figure S3). Each trimer unit is connected to six other trimer units via ligand molecules forming a 6-c connected network (d,e).

elements.content: (a, b) The asymmetric unit present in compounds 1 and 2, respectively; (c) SBU unit Mn3 (OCO)6 of compound 1; (d, e) the 6-c connected network in compounds 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a, b) The asymmetric unit present in compounds 1 and 2, respectively; (c) SBU unit Mn3 (OCO)6 of compound 1; (d, e) the 6-c connected network in compounds 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: The compounds 1a and 2a are classified in another category. Those were crystallized in the orthorhombic system with space group P212121 and C2221, respectively. They are structurally similar and have 1-D Mn−O−Mn chain as SBU (a).
elements.clean_text: The compounds 1a and 2a are classified in another category. Those were crystallized in the orthorhombic system with space group P212121 and C2221, respectively. They are structurally similar and have 1-D Mn-O-Mn chain as SBU (a).

elements.content: (a) One-dimensional Mn–O–Mn chain in 1a and (b) 3D network structure of compound 1a.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) One-dimensional Mn-O-Mn chain in 1a and (b) 3D network structure of compound 1a.

elements.content: The 1D chains are interconnected by linker molecules to form the 3D network (b). The metal ions are six coordinated and among six, four come from dicarboxylate organic linker molecules and two from acetic acid. There are two kinds of metal ions with different coordination environments. Mn1 is bonded to one acetic acid, whereas Mn2 is bonded with two acetic acid molecules (a and S4–S5). The acetate ion bridges the metal centers to form the 1D infinite Mn–O–Mn chain.
elements.clean_text: The 1D chains are interconnected by linker molecules to form the 3D network (b). The metal ions are six coordinated and among six, four come from dicarboxylate organic linker molecules and two from acetic acid. There are two kinds of metal ions with different coordination environments. Mn1 is bonded to one acetic acid, whereas Mn2 is bonded with two acetic acid molecules (a and S4-S5). The acetate ion bridges the metal centers to form the 1D infinite Mn-O-Mn chain.

elements.content: The phase purity of all structures were checked using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies. The PXRD pattern of all as-synthesized compounds were exactly matched as that of the simulated one (Figure S6). The intrared (IR) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements also have been carried out for more structural information (Figures S7 and S8). The first step of weight loss in the compounds 1 and 2 are due to the loss of coordinated solvent molecules, and that in compounds 1a and 2a are due to lattice solvent and organic cation molecules.
elements.clean_text: The phase purity of all structures were checked using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies. The PXRD pattern of all as-synthesized compounds were exactly matched as that of the simulated one (Figure S6). The intrared (IR) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements also have been carried out for more structural information (Figures S7 and S8). The first step of weight loss in the compounds 1 and 2 are due to the loss of coordinated solvent molecules, and that in compounds 1a and 2a are due to lattice solvent and organic cation molecules.

elements.content: The chirality in crystalline materials is very important, and it brings vital attention in various applications. The chiral metal organic compounds can be synthesized either by the use of homochiral molecular building blocks (MBBs) or by spontaneous resolution of chiral centers and chiral nets comprised of achiral MBBs. Use of a homochiral ligand to synthesize a chiral compound is an expensive method. Hence it is still a challenge to design an organic ligand combining both flexibility and directionality that can induce chirality through spontaneous resolution during the controlled assembly by local destruction of achiral asymmetric unit. Bulk chirality can be created in MOFs which exhibit a network topology that is inherently chiral because of the spatial organization of achiral building blocks. But unfortunately, spontaneous resolution sometimes leads to the formation of racemic mixtures or conglomerates. In the present work two compounds were crystallized with a chiral space group containing a 21 screw axis and they are optically inactive. These were formed with intertwined helical connectivity, and it may be due to the racemic twined crystals.
elements.clean_text: The chirality in crystalline materials is very important, and it brings vital attention in various applications. The chiral metal organic compounds can be synthesized either by the use of homochiral molecular building blocks (MBBs) or by spontaneous resolution of chiral centers and chiral nets comprised of achiral MBBs. Use of a homochiral ligand to synthesize a chiral compound is an expensive method. Hence it is still a challenge to design an organic ligand combining both flexibility and directionality that can induce chirality through spontaneous resolution during the controlled assembly by local destruction of achiral asymmetric unit. Bulk chirality can be created in MOFs which exhibit a network topology that is inherently chiral because of the spatial organization of achiral building blocks. But unfortunately, spontaneous resolution sometimes leads to the formation of racemic mixtures or conglomerates. In the present work two compounds were crystallized with a chiral space group containing a 21 screw axis and they are optically inactive. These were formed with intertwined helical connectivity, and it may be due to the racemic twined crystals.

elements.content: The compounds 1a and 2a were crystallized in a chiral space group, and it might be due to the absence of symmetry around the metal asymmetric center (Figure S9). The analysis of the optical activity of compounds 1a and 2a using the circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy shows that these are optically inactive, because the spectrum does not have any significant spectral behavior that corresponds to the enantiomeric excess (Figure S10). We have investigated the structure in more detail to understand what could be the reason for optical inactivity. Then we realized that in all the compounds a 1D chain is connected by ligands to form two different helices in the network (b and S5). The way by which the ligands are connected to the 1D chain leads to the formation of a helical structure (). Interestingly we observed that both the right-handed and left-handed helices exist in the same structure, leading to a conglomerate that lacks the optical activity. The high flack parameter (0.33(2) for 1a and 0.32(3) for 2a) of both structures (without TWIN refinement) also proved that the compounds were not formed with absolute structure (see Supporting Information, Tables S11 and S12).
elements.clean_text: The compounds 1a and 2a were crystallized in a chiral space group, and it might be due to the absence of symmetry around the metal asymmetric center (Figure S9). The analysis of the optical activity of compounds 1a and 2a using the circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy shows that these are optically inactive, because the spectrum does not have any significant spectral behavior that corresponds to the enantiomeric excess (Figure S10). We have investigated the structure in more detail to understand what could be the reason for optical inactivity. Then we realized that in all the compounds a 1D chain is connected by ligands to form two different helices in the network (b and S5). The way by which the ligands are connected to the 1D chain leads to the formation of a helical structure (). Interestingly we observed that both the right-handed and left-handed helices exist in the same structure, leading to a conglomerate that lacks the optical activity. The high flack parameter (0.33(2) for 1a and 0.32(3) for 2a) of both structures (without TWIN refinement) also proved that the compounds were not formed with absolute structure (see Supporting Information, Tables S11 and S12).

elements.content: Helical structure of compound 1a.
elements.clean_text: 3  Helical structure of compound 1a.

elements.content: One can have a chemical control over the growth of different facets to facilitate the anisotropic crystal growth. We have reported here the potential use of monocarboxylic acid as a structure-directing agent which induces the structural transformation as well as chirality. The only difference in the synthetic conditions of compounds 1a and 2a compared to compounds 1 and 2 is the use of acetic acid. This observation excited us to explore the possibility of structural transformation between the above-mentioned two categories of structures by using the acetic acid. So we have done it by immersing the crystals of 1 and 2 in acetic acid and heated at 100 °C for few days, and we have observed the formation of crystals of 1a and 2a (see Supporting Information and ). It is very clear from the crystal images that the acetic acid has an important role in controlling the morphology also. We have selected acetic acid since it has high metal binding ability and directionality. Usually monocarboxylic acids are used to control the rate of nucleation in crystal growth and thus to control the shape and size of MOF particle. But for the first time we have shown that acetic acid can be used for the structural transformation and that can induce the chirality also. However, the postsynthetic modification of achiral MOF to form the design targeted chiral MOF has been reported.
elements.clean_text: One can have a chemical control over the growth of different facets to facilitate the anisotropic crystal growth. We have reported here the potential use of monocarboxylic acid as a structure-directing agent which induces the structural transformation as well as chirality. The only difference in the synthetic conditions of compounds 1a and 2a compared to compounds 1 and 2 is the use of acetic acid. This observation excited us to explore the possibility of structural transformation between the above-mentioned two categories of structures by using the acetic acid. So we have done it by immersing the crystals of 1 and 2 in acetic acid and heated at 100 °C for few days, and we have observed the formation of crystals of 1a and 2a (see Supporting Information and ). It is very clear from the crystal images that the acetic acid has an important role in controlling the morphology also. We have selected acetic acid since it has high metal binding ability and directionality. Usually monocarboxylic acids are used to control the rate of nucleation in crystal growth and thus to control the shape and size of MOF particle. But for the first time we have shown that acetic acid can be used for the structural transformation and that can induce the chirality also. However, the postsynthetic modification of achiral MOF to form the design targeted chiral MOF has been reported.

elements.clean_text: 4  Microscopic images of compounds 1 to 2 and 1a to 2a.

elements.content: In the present case when the metal ions react with dicarboxylate linkers alone under solvothermal conditions the crystals with an irregular shape were formed, but after transformation crystals were formed with a specific needle-like shape. This may be due to the controlled nucleation and oriented growth of crystals. During the crystallization process, the metal ion interacts with the acetate ion much faster than dicarboxylate ion due to its strong coordination ability. This might lead to the destruction of the SBU of the original structures and induces transformation.
elements.clean_text: In the present case when the metal ions react with dicarboxylate linkers alone under solvothermal conditions the crystals with an irregular shape were formed, but after transformation crystals were formed with a specific needle-like shape. This may be due to the controlled nucleation and oriented growth of crystals. During the crystallization process, the metal ion interacts with the acetate ion much faster than dicarboxylate ion due to its strong coordination ability. This might lead to the destruction of the SBU of the original structures and induces transformation.

elements.content: Monocarboxylate (here acetic acid) impedes the coordination between metal and dicarboxylate linkers. The metal acetate diffuses into the framework and breaks the SBU. The metal acetate binds to the terminal metal ion of the trimer unit and blocks the further growth in that particular direction (Figure S13). The new metal center also adopts an octahedral coordination geometry with dicarboxylate ligands and then connects to other trimer units forming the 1D chain. Thus, the impeded metal acetate forms a bridge between the two trimer units. The coordinated solvent molecules were also removed, and the dicarboxylate ligand molecules fill the remaining coordination sites of the new metal center. One can assume that the transformation essentially results in anisotropic growth and here the acetic acid triggers the growth mechanism by varying the crystal growth rates along different facets. The prediction of crystal morphology can be done by considering the relative growth rates of the different crystal faces. In principle, a crystal should grow in a particular direction unless the energetics is changed along a particular facet. Thus, the growth rates of facets in different orientations are proportional to the attachment energy of growth units. The final morphology of the crystal is often determined by the consequence of the competitive growth of (hkl), (h00), and (hk0) faces, and the structure is formed with facets at a slower growth rate. As shown in Figures S14–S15, for compounds 1 and 2 the dominating facets are either two of the (hk0), (0kl), and (h0l) planes. The growth in these orientations is slower than other planes, whereas for compounds 1a and 2a the slower growth happens in either one of those orientations only, and therefore it results in the formation of long needles not the blocks or plates.
elements.clean_text: Monocarboxylate (here acetic acid) impedes the coordination between metal and dicarboxylate linkers. The metal acetate diffuses into the framework and breaks the SBU. The metal acetate binds to the terminal metal ion of the trimer unit and blocks the further growth in that particular direction (Figure S13). The new metal center also adopts an octahedral coordination geometry with dicarboxylate ligands and then connects to other trimer units forming the 1D chain. Thus, the impeded metal acetate forms a bridge between the two trimer units. The coordinated solvent molecules were also removed, and the dicarboxylate ligand molecules fill the remaining coordination sites of the new metal center. One can assume that the transformation essentially results in anisotropic growth and here the acetic acid triggers the growth mechanism by varying the crystal growth rates along different facets. The prediction of crystal morphology can be done by considering the relative growth rates of the different crystal faces. In principle, a crystal should grow in a particular direction unless the energetics is changed along a particular facet. Thus, the growth rates of facets in different orientations are proportional to the attachment energy of growth units. The final morphology of the crystal is often determined by the consequence of the competitive growth of (hkl), (h00), and (hk0) faces, and the structure is formed with facets at a slower growth rate. As shown in Figures S14-S15, for compounds 1 and 2 the dominating facets are either two of the (hk0), (0kl), and (h0l) planes. The growth in these orientations is slower than other planes, whereas for compounds 1a and 2a the slower growth happens in either one of those orientations only, and therefore it results in the formation of long needles not the blocks or plates.

elements.content: Among those two categories, one set of structures contains the Mn-trimer cluster, and other set contains Mn–O–Mn chain as the SBU. In order to analyze the influence of structural features on the magnetic properties, we have performed the magnetic measurements on all the compounds and correlated them with the corresponding structures.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Among those two categories, one set of structures contains the Mn-trimer cluster, and other set contains Mn-O-Mn chain as the SBU. In order to analyze the influence of structural features on the magnetic properties, we have performed the magnetic measurements on all the compounds and correlated them with the corresponding structures.

elements.content: χ­(T) of compounds 1 and 1a measured at an applied field H = 1 T is shown in , panels a and b, respectively. At high temperatures, χ­(T) of both the compounds increases with decreasing temperatures, following the Curie–Weiss (CW) behavior as expected in the paramagnetic regime. At T max ≃ 3.16 and 8.66 K, it passes through a broad maximum for 1 and 1a, respectively, indicating short-range magnetic ordering, which is a typical behavior of low-dimensional magnets. Compound 1 does not show any signature of magnetic long-range ordering down to 2.1 K, whereas compound 1a undergoes a magnetic long-range ordering at T N ≃ 4.5 K, as evident from the splitting of zero field cooled (ZFC) and field cooled (FC) susceptibilities.
elements.clean_text:
Compounds 1 and 1a 

χ(T) of compounds 1 and 1a measured at an applied field H = 1 T is shown in , panels a and b, respectively. At high temperatures, χ(T) of both the compounds increases with decreasing temperatures, following the Curie-Weiss (CW) behavior as expected in the paramagnetic regime. At T max ≃ 3.16 and 8.66 K, it passes through a broad maximum for 1 and 1a, respectively, indicating short-range magnetic ordering, which is a typical behavior of low-dimensional magnets. Compound 1 does not show any signature of magnetic long-range ordering down to 2.1 K, whereas compound 1a undergoes a magnetic long-range ordering at T N ≃ 4.5 K, as evident from the splitting of zero field cooled (ZFC) and field cooled (FC) susceptibilities.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility (χ) vs temperature (T) for 1 and 1a measured at an applied magnetic field of H = 1 T. The solid line represents the 1D fit as described in the text. Upper inset in (a) and lower inset in (b): 1/χ vs T fitted by a CW law using eq as shown by the red solid line; upper inset in (b): the ZFC and FC susceptibilities measured under an applied field of 100 Oe in the low temperature region.
elements.clean_text: 5  Magnetic susceptibility (χ) vs temperature (T) for 1 and 1a measured at an applied magnetic field of H = 1 T. The solid line represents the 1D fit as described in the text. Upper inset in (a) and lower inset in (b): 1/χ vs T fitted by a CW law using eq   as shown by the red solid line; upper inset in (b): the ZFC and FC susceptibilities measured under an applied field of 100 Oe in the low temperature region.

elements.content: In order to extract the magnetic parameters, we have performed a CW fit to the 1/χ vs. T data at high temperatures using the following expression: χ ( T ) = χ 0 + C T + θ C W where χ0 is temperature-independent parameters which includes contributions of core diamagnetic susceptibility (χcore) and Van-Vleck paramagnetism (χvv). The second term is the CW law with C being the Curie constant and θCW being the characteristic CW temperature. The parameters were obtained by fitting to the high temperature data (T ≥ 50 K for 1 and T ≥ 100 K for 1a) and tabulated in .
elements.clean_text: In order to extract the magnetic parameters, we have performed a CW fit to the 1/χ vs. T data at high temperatures using the following expression: 1    χ  ( T )  =   χ   0   +   C   T +   θ   C W       where χ0 is temperature-independent parameters which includes contributions of core diamagnetic susceptibility (χcore) and Van-Vleck paramagnetism (χvv). The second term is the CW law with C being the Curie constant and θCW being the characteristic CW temperature. The parameters were obtained by fitting  to the high temperature data (T ≥ 50 K for 1 and T ≥ 100 K for 1a) and tabulated in .

elements.content:
The effective moment ( μ eff = 3 k B C N A ) calculated for S = 5/2 from the value of C and the corresponding value of g (μeff = g√S(S + 1)) are also tabulated.

Heat Capacity

The heat capacity (C p ) was measured for compounds 1a and 2a in the low temperature region at zero applied field to detect the occurrence of magnetic long-range ordering. shows the C p(T) for both the compounds. A clear anomaly at 4.36 and 4.94 K for compounds 1a and 2a, respectively, confirms the onset magnetic long-range ordering, consistent with the χ­(T) measurements.

elements.content: For all the compounds, the calculated effective moment μeff is close to the expected spin only value of μ eff = g S ( S +1) μ B ≃ 5.92 μ B for Mn2+ (S = 5/2), assuming g = 2. Small variation is likely due to a slight change in the g-value as indicated in the last column of . For compounds 1, 1a, 2, and 2a, a broad maximum in χ­(T) data indicates low-dimensional character. The χ­(T) data were fitted using a 1D chain model (see Supporting Information). The parameters obtained from the fit are listed in .

The χ(T) data were fitted using a 1D chain model (see Supporting Information). The parameters obtained from the fit are listed in .

The temperature ranges used for fitting are (3–380 K), (4–380 K), (7–380 K), (7.3–380 K), and (8.3–380 K) for compounds 1, 1a, 2, and 2a, respectively.

The transformation from compounds 1 and 2 to 1a and 2a, respectively, results in a reduction in the interatomic distance between Mn2+ ions. Thus, the trimer arrangement in compounds 1 and 2 with large intertrimer distance transforms into a a uniform spin chain of Mn2+ ions. As seen in , the 1D spin chain model fits to the χ­(T) data (Supporting Information, eq 2) giving a higher value of exchange interaction (J/k B) for 1a and 2a compared to compounds 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The transformation from compounds 1 and 2 to 1a and 2a, respectively, results in a reduction in the interatomic distance between Mn2+ ions. Thus, the trimer arrangement in compounds 1 and 2 with large intertrimer distance transforms into a a uniform spin chain of Mn2+ ions. As seen in , the 1D spin chain model fits to the χ(T) data (Supporting Information, eq 2) giving a higher value of exchange interaction (J/k B) for 1a and 2a compared to compounds 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: In real 1D systems, in addition to the dominant intrachain interaction, a weak interchain coupling exists, in which the system undergoes a magnetic long-range ordering at a finite temperature. Compounds 1a and 2a undergo a magnetic long-range ordering at T N ≃ 4.36 and 4.94 K, respectively, due to the weak interchain (J ⊥) interaction. Using the Oguchi criterion, one can estimate the strength of the interchain interaction as k B T N | J | = 4 S ( S + 1 ) 3 I ( η ) where η = J ⊥/J and I(η) is the a triple integral with different components of the wave vector q . The numerical values of I(η) for different values of η are found out by simulating the data in . Using the appropriate values of T N and J, the value of I(η) was found to be 4.176 and 3.92, for 1a and 2a, respectively. From these values of η, J/kB was calculated to be 0.0884 and 0.0996 K for compounds 1a and 2a, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In real 1D systems, in addition to the dominant intrachain interaction, a weak interchain coupling exists, in which the system undergoes a magnetic long-range ordering at a finite temperature. Compounds 1a and 2a undergo a magnetic long-range ordering at T N ≃ 4.36 and 4.94 K, respectively, due to the weak interchain (J ⊥) interaction. Using the Oguchi criterion, one can estimate the strength of the interchain interaction as 4        k   B     T   N     | J |   =   4 S  ( S + 1 )    3 I  ( η )      where η = J ⊥/J and I(η) is the a triple integral with different components of the wave vector  q . The numerical values of I(η) for different values of η are found out by simulating the data in . Using the appropriate values of T N and J, the value of I(η) was found to be 4.176 and 3.92, for 1a and 2a, respectively. From these values of η, J/kB was calculated to be 0.0884 and 0.0996 K for compounds 1a and 2a, respectively.

elements.content: We have synthesized four new structures based on Mn2+ as the metal source and functionalized terephthalate as the ligand. It was very interesting to observe how the acetic acid acts as a ligand rather than a modulator over here. We noted that the acetic acid which is a well-known capping agent was the main driving force for the structural transformation. The morphogenesis due to anisotropic growth in crystals also was examined using PXRD and microscopic imaging studies. We have also analyzed how acetate bonding creates chirality in the framework structures. The possible mechanistic pathway for the transformation was proposed based on the structural information. The structural transformation leads to a significant increase in the exchange interactions between Mn2+ ions and the occurrence of magnetic long-range ordering at low temperature in the structures. A detailed analysis of the magnetic data underscores the structure–property relationship.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have synthesized four new structures based on Mn2+ as the metal source and functionalized terephthalate as the ligand. It was very interesting to observe how the acetic acid acts as a ligand rather than a modulator over here. We noted that the acetic acid which is a well-known capping agent was the main driving force for the structural transformation. The morphogenesis due to anisotropic growth in crystals also was examined using PXRD and microscopic imaging studies. We have also analyzed how acetate bonding creates chirality in the framework structures. The possible mechanistic pathway for the transformation was proposed based on the structural information. The structural transformation leads to a significant increase in the exchange interactions between Mn2+ ions and the occurrence of magnetic long-range ordering at low temperature in the structures. A detailed analysis of the magnetic data underscores the structure-property relationship.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid in 3 mL of N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA). Then the whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF (N,N′-dimethylformamide) many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Compound 2: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid in 3 mL of DMA and sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Compound 1a: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and 2 mL of acetic acid was added to this. The solution was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was put into a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 6 days. Colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Compound 2a: To the solution of 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn­(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 3 mL of methanol, 2 mL of acetic acid was added and the mixture was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in oven for 3 days. The collected colorless crystals were washed with DMF many times and dried under a vacuum for further use.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Compound 1: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid in 3 mL of N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA). Then the whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF (N,N'-dimethylformamide) many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Compound 2: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and mixed with 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid in 3 mL of DMA and sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 3 days. The colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Compound 1a: 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of methanol and 2 mL of acetic acid was added to this. The solution was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.089 g (0.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was put into a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in the oven for 6 days. Colorless crystals were formed, washed with DMF many times, and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Compound 2a: To the solution of 0.137 g (0.53 mmol) of Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 3 mL of methanol, 2 mL of acetic acid was added and the mixture was kept undisturbed for some time. Then 0.098 g (0.5 mmol) of 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid dissolved in 3 mL of DMA was added to it, and the mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The whole mixture was taken in a closed glass vial and kept at 100 °C in oven for 3 days. The collected colorless crystals were washed with DMF many times and dried under a vacuum for further use.

Magnetic Parameters Obtained from the 1D Chain Model (<ext-link xlink:href="http://pubs.acs.org/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.cgd.6b01168/suppl_file/cg6b01168_si_001.pdf">Supporting Information</ext-link>, eq 2) Fit to the χ­(<italic>T</italic>) Data for Compounds <bold>1</bold>, <bold>1a</bold>, <bold>2</bold>, and <bold>2a</bold>, Respectively<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="tbl2-fn1"></xref> compounds χ 0 (cm3/mol Mn) J/k B (K) 1 –4.63 × 10–3 0.30 2 7.32 × 10–4 1.02 1a 1.33 × 10–4 1.56 2a 6.47 × 10–4 1.66

The temperature ranges used for fitting are (3–380 K), (4–380 K), (7–380 K), (7.3–380 K), and (8.3–380 K) for compounds 1, 1a, 2, and 2a, respectively.
